ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot about python and data science.

I learned several useful data science and econometric techniques to work with COVID-19 pandemic-related data. I also learned a lot of foundational Python (working in pandas, numpy, matplotlib, seaborn, regression packages, etc.).
Statistics and learned more covid-19 data
I learned how to process data in python and use various statistical tools to investigate COVID-19 pandemic variables.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No weaknesses. Just that in the last two weeks, the skills really ramped up without a ton of explanation. I would have appreciated if they were reviewed more slowly.

Strengths: great teacher, very fair problem sets, very fair exams
Weaknesses: the format was a two-hour seminar that meets once a week, so sometimes staring at a Python notebook for two hours causes burnout
Professor is amazing and super accommodating!
Lectures and homework were very well organized. I would have appreciated more explanation on how some of the code worked, but there's always documentation and the internet.

One strength is that this class provides a lot of hands-on practice, which helped me get familiar with python (having previously not taken YData). One weakness of the class is that some of the lectures felt a bit disorganized, and we would often cover many different topics together in one lecture. The slides were also not particularly informative in some cases.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It worked fine I guess, especially with the screen-sharing aspect. I just want in-person classes.
Office hours, peer tutors, very accessible with emails, study groups within the class
I thought the lectures often felt long for zoom but i liked office hours!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yeah. Super super easy credit. A true gut. But at the same time very interesting and Professor Yan is so nice.
Absolutely! Very relevant topic -- and it was very cool to be able to actually make the maps, charts, graphs, and statistics on the pandemic that are ubiquitously circulated in the news and media.
Yes! It is a good fifth class.

I would recommend this course if you wanted to pick up python. Keep in mind that many of the statistical techniques used in this class are very specific to the given topic, so if you're really interested in it, this would be a good class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
